Fleeting faces. Truth slips out.
<[silence:2400]>
"Microexpressions" are tiny, involuntary flashes of emotion—lasting 1/25th to 1/5th of a second—that reveal what someone actually feels.<[silence:1200]>
Like a camera shutter opening and closing too fast to see the photo.<[silence:2400]

Most people fake smiles or hide anger, but microexpressions betray the real emotion before the brain can stop it.<[silence:1200]>
Seven core types exist: happiness, sadness, fear, disgust, anger, surprise, contempt—each with its own muscle twitch.<[silence:1200]>
A true smile crinkles the eyes. A fake one doesn’t.<[silence:1200]>
Contempt? One corner of the mouth lifts slightly, like someone just smelled spoiled milk.<[silence:2400]

Police interrogators, poker players, and therapists train to spot these.<[silence:1200]>
In 1966, psychologists Haggard and Isaacs slowed film to 1/16th speed and caught patients lying by their micro-flinches.<[silence:1200]>
Today, AI scans faces for these tells—though humans still outperform machines at reading subtle contempt.<[silence:2400]

Lie detection isn’t foolproof, but microexpressions are the closest thing to a human polygraph.<[silence:1200]>
The face leaks secrets before the mind even knows it’s talking.<[silence:1200]>

Deception cues.
Universal emotions.
The speed of instinct.
